arm_group.description: High-tone external muscle stimulation 5 times within 10 days
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation 5 times within 10 days

brief_summary.textblock:
Sciatica is a common pain problem that affects not only the patient but also constitutes a
      socioeconomic burden and thus affects the whole society. So far, current pharmacologic
      therapies are inadequate for many patients. Therefore, we evaluated application of high-tone
      external muscle stimulation (HTEMS) compared to transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation
      (TENS) on radicular pain associated with sciatica.

clinical_study.brief_title: High-tone External Muscle Stimulation for Pain Reduction

detailed_description.textblock:
Hospital patients (n=100) with chronic sciatica and stable oral analgesic regimen were
      included into this randomized controlled cross-over trial. Each intervention was
      administered for a period of 45 min 5 times within 10 days, with a 3-day wash-out period
      before cross-over. Health impairments had been assessed using the visual analog scales (VAS)
      for radicular pain before and after intervention and differences in radicular pain between
      groups were analysed with the Mann-Whitney test.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  sciatica due to degenerative spine disorders

          -  stable oral analgesic regimen

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  history of drug or alcohol abuse

          -  cardiac pacemaker or defibrillator

          -  pregnancy

clinical_study.official_title: High-tone External Muscle Stimulation for Treatment of Chronic Pain

primary_outcome.description: Back pain measured by an 11-point visual analogue scale (VAS) with 0 = none and 10 = worst pain imaginable

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: West German Center of Diabetes and Health

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
